Row.Text: Fishing is an ancient practice that dates back to at least the beginning of the Paleolithic period about 40,000 years ago. Isotopic analysis of the skeletal remains of Tianyuan man, a 40,000 year old modern human from eastern Asia, has shown that he regularly consumed freshwater fish. Archaeology features such as shell middens, discarded fish bones and cave paintings show that sea foods were important for survival and consumed in significant quantities. During this period, most people lived a hunter-gatherer lifestyle and were, of necessity, constantly on the move. However, where there are early examples of permanent settlements, they are almost always associated with fishing as a major source of food.

Allows you to build [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Work Boats[ENDCOLOR], useful for harvesting resources in the water like [ICON_RES_FISH] [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Fish[ENDCOLOR], [ICON_RES_PEARLS] [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Pearls[ENDCOLOR], [ICON_RES_WHALE] [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Whales[ENDCOLOR] and [ICON_RES_CRAB] [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Crabs[ENDCOLOR].
[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB]"Give a man a fish, and you feed him for a day.[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] Teach a man to fish, and you feed him for a lifetime."[NEWLINE][TAB][TAB] - Lao Tzu[NEWLINE][TAB]

Set.Text: Allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Galley[ENDCOLOR], the first Ranged Naval Unit. Also allows land units to [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Embark[ENDCOLOR] onto water tiles.

Allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Trireme[ENDCOLOR], the first Melee Naval Unit. Also allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Lighthouse[ENDCOLOR] in coastal cities, improving [ICON_FOOD] Food output from water tiles, speeding their growth.

Allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Galleass[ENDCOLOR], a powerful Ranged Naval Unit. Also allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Harbor[ENDCOLOR], which creates trade routes from cities to the capital over the water, producing [ICON_GOLD] Gold. Additionally, the [ICON_GOLD] Gold yield from Fishing Boats is increased.

Allows you to build the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Caravel[ENDCOLOR], the first Naval Unit capable of exploring the world's oceans, and the [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Observatory[ENDCOLOR], which provides a significant [ICON_RESEARCH] Science boost. Also provides +1 [ICON_MOVES] Movement to embarked land units and allows them to cross ocean tiles.

A galley is a type of ship propelled by rowers that originated in the Mediterranean region and was used for warfare, trade and piracy from the first millennium BC. This early type of galley was also known as a bireme and consisted of two decks of oars. They were first created by the seafaring Phoenecians of the Mediterranean in early antiquity. Later on, these ships evolved and a third row of oars was added by the addition of an outrigger to the hull, a projecting construction that allowed for more room for the projecting oars. These new galleys were called triremes.

The Galley is the first ranged naval unit available to civilizations in the game. It can bombard cities and attack units at sea or on land near the coast. It is also useful for limited exploration (it cannot enter Deep Ocean hexes outside of the city borders unless it is from Polynesia).

Row.Text: Ancient Era Naval Unit used to wrest control of the seas through ranged attacks on units and cities.

Set.Text: The Trireme is the first melee naval unit available to civilizations in the game. It engages units at sea or coastal cities (which it can conquer). The Trireme is useful for clearing barbarian ships out of home waters and for limited exploration (it cannot enter Deep Ocean hexes outside of the city borders unless it is from Polynesia).
A very powerful naval melee unit, used to dominate the seas during the Industrial Era. Also specializes in attacking coastal cities.
Can embark and move over Oceans immediately. +1 [ICON_MOVES] Movement and +1 Sight when embarked. +10% [ICON_STRENGTH] Combat Strength bonus if within 2 tiles of a Moai.
Heavily-armored naval unit of the Renaissance Era that is extremely difficult to kill. Only Korea may build it. Replaces the Caravel.

The Turtle Ship is a Korean unique unit and replaces the Caravel. The Turtle Ship has a more powerful attack than the Caravel, and is extremely difficult to destroy. However, it is slower and has less sight, so it is not as useful for exploration.
Can embark onto [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Water Tiles[ENDCOLOR]. Embarked units can enter Ocean and have +1 Sight and +1 [ICON_MOVES] Movement.
Can embark onto [COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Water Tiles[ENDCOLOR]. Embarked units can enter Ocean and have +1 Sight and +1 [ICON_MOVES] Movement.

Only the Byzantines may build this unit. It is a ranged naval unit that replaces the Galley and attacks with lethal Greek Fire. This unit is stronger than the Galley and also receives an additional +20% strength against other naval units. It cannot enter Deep Ocean tiles.

Only the Carthaginians may build this unit. It is a stronger and faster version of the Trireme. Like the Trireme, it is a melee attack unit, engaging units at sea or cities (but it has no ranged attack). The Quinquereme cannot enter Deep Ocean tiles.
All melee naval units have the Barbary Pirate promotion, allowing them to capture defeated ships. Pay only one-third the usual cost for naval unit maintenance.
